prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: O18O search + other lines - 1st spectral setup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: One pointing is a deep integration towards BN-KL One pointing is a deep integration towards H2 peak Several lines are surveyed together with several spectral setups, always keeping O18O in the band.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: Using the most compact configuration, we will be able to map the two regions with a maximum angular size (11") slightly larger than the expected size of the source (5-10"). From the Herschel detection, we derive a column density of 5.6E16 cm-2 if the source is 5" in size. The line intensity, supposing that the emitting region temperature is 125 K (slightly above water ice evaporation), is expected to be 25 mK (3 km/s FWHM). A 5 sigma detection would therefore require a 5 mK (= 2 mJy) sensitivity. We will use a velocity resolution of 0.7 km/s and we will smooth the data to 3" to increase the sensitivity. If the source is 10" in diameter, the signal will be four times weaker (column density of 1.4E16 cm-2) but the sensitivity can be proportionally increased by smoothing to 6", keeping the detection at the 5 sigma level, so the source exact size is not a limitation. From the velocity map (Fig. 2), we do not expect the source size to exceed the maximum recoverable ALMA source size at this frequency. With 3" resolution, we get 5 mK in 0.7 km/s channels in 2.5 hr per source (2 mJy sensitivity). To spread this integration time on 5 tunings (= 5 Science goals), we reduce each individual science goal sensitivity to 4.5 mJy, so that the average of the 5 will provide the requested 2 mJy sensiti- vity for the O18O line (and all other lines in the same backend), while the sensitivity for the rest of the 14.9 GHz band will be 4.5 mJy.
Imaging requirements: Two single pointings will be done, one towards each of the two sources of interest encompassed in the original 44" Herschel beam (Fig.3).
Correlator setup: Correlator is setup in five different tunings with one band always tuned to the 16O18O line. The 3 other bands (all 4 with a 0.93 GHz band- width and 0.7 km/s resolution) are moved around to cover the maximum frequency range (14.9 GHz). The velocity resolution is a compromise between the largest possible frequency coverage and the necessary resolution to separate confusion limited components as much as possible. It is spectral averaged to 2 (0.56 MHz instead of 0.45 MHz) to reduce the datarate below 12 MBit/sec with only a small degradation of the velocity resolution

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: O18O search + other lines - 2nd spectral setup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: One pointing is a deep integration towards BN-KL One pointing is a deep integration towards H2 peak Several lines are surveyed together with several spectral setups, always keeping O18O in the band.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: All technical justifications are identical to the first one since the main goal (detection of the O18O line) is kept throughout the 5 settings to be averaged together at the end. The three other bands are moved around to collect a maximum of different species to help characterize the different subregions which will appear in the primary beam. See technical justification of the first ScienceGoal for more details

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The gas-phase abundance of O2 in cold, well-shielded clouds has been determined by SWAS, Odin, and Herschel to be 2 to 3 orders of magnitude lower than predicted. Explaining this discrepancy is a very strong test of chemical models and our understanding of interstellar chemistry. Herschel has had a major impact, but has not resolved the controversy. One of its limitations has been its relatively large beam size that dilutes the signal from sources of small angular size, and prevents identification of the emitting source and its size in the complex case of Orion OMC1. Unlike the common isotopologue, 18O16O can be observed from the ground. The 234 GHz line is the best candidate and should be detectable with ALMA, and ALMA only. With a synthesized beam size of a few arcsec, we will be able to pinpoint the location of the source of the oxygen emission and its characteristics, and find the explanation for the general absence but selective enhancement of O2 in interstellar clouds. An additional product of this study will be a deep survey in 14 GHz of band 6, with a sensitivity never achieved in standard surveys. This will help clarify why O2 behaves so differently than expected

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), California Institute of Technology
